image.altText: A man stares down the barrel of a camera while sitting in a room, wearing all black.

props.synopsis: Twenty-four-year-old Alex Ophel makes a brief appearance in court, charged with two counts of attempted murder, two counts of assault and one count of possessing an object to be used to kill.

title.children: Man charged with attempted murder over stabbing of two female students at ANU

image.altText: a fireman conducting a hazards reduction controlled  burn

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meteorology raises the NSW Far South Coast's fire danger rating to catastrophic for the rest of the day, due to stronger than forecast winds.

title.children: Far South Coast fire danger rating elevated to catastrophic as dozens of schools close

image.altText: A relaxed young man wears an open-collared shirt and looks left of the camera, a lamp and door behind him are out of focus

props.synopsis: When Senator Steele-John became the youngest-ever senator, he put his new paycheque toward removing "that knot of fear in the stomach" that came with his family's debt.

title.children: Jordon Steele-John on how paying down his family's debt was a 'privilege'

image.altText: The ACT Supreme Court towards dusk.

props.synopsis: A Canberra court hears details of a series of burglaries — including the theft of two French bulldogs, several Audis and other cars — involving two 20-year-old men, one of whom allegedly joked he was taking one of the dogs "hostage".

title.children: 'Simply reckless' men who stole two French bulldogs and several cars face Canberra court

image.altText: A search and rescue worker in burnt Lahaina

props.synopsis: As Australia experiences "bigger … hotter fires", experts say buffel grass — which is now found in every state and territory — poses a growing bushfire risk.

title.children: Invasive grass with role in deadly Maui blaze 'absolutely a threat' to Australian lives

image.altText: woman runs in shade on Sydney beach

props.synopsis: A record spell of September heat is baking southern states, with temperatures as much as 18 degrees Celsius above average.

title.children: A cool change is coming to south-eastern Australia — but it will get even hotter first

image.altText: A photo of a large orange painting of a harbour with palm trees at the bottom, a pier at hte top and boats in among the water

props.synopsis: In 2007, a gallery assistant made a discovery that rocked the Australian art world and led to one of the most controversial, high-profile and enduring art mysteries.

title.children: How one of Australia's most controversial art mysteries unfolded

image.altText: A 3D printed oil pump jack in front of the OPEC logo.

props.synopsis: OPEC has run an oil cartel for decades, but as the world moves away from fossil fuels, could its influence be waning, asks Nassim Khadem.

title.children: '$4.7b in profits a day': A powerful cartel still controls the world's oil and is why you're paying more for petrol

image.altText: A hand holding a fuel nozzle putting petrol in a white car

props.synopsis: People are feeling the pinch around the country as national average petrol prices top 204.4 cents per litre. But where are you at in the price cycle?

title.children: With school holidays imminent for some, will petrol prices drop any time soon? Your capital city breakdown

image.altText: The castle at Disney World in Orlando Florida

props.synopsis: This morning's news, as it happened.

title.children: Extreme fire danger in NSW forces schools to close, and wild bear's surprise visit to Disney World ends with successful relocation. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Russell Brand

props.synopsis: They're allegations even the most beloved of Hollywood A-Listers would struggle to explain away, but Russell Brand and his millions of online followers exist in a different dimension, far away from cancel culture.

title.children: It's too late to cancel Russell Brand — he did it himself a decade ago

image.altText: Russell Brand leaves the Troubabour Wembley Park theatre. He is wearing sunglasses at night.

props.synopsis: A woman who accused British actor and comedian Russell Brand of sexual and emotional abuse says his denial of the allegations is "insulting".

title.children: 'Laughable and insulting': Russell Brand accuser hits out at his denials in fresh interview

image.altText: Abandoned cars on the main island of Tongatapu in the Kingdom of Tonga

props.synopsis: The Kingdom of Tonga looks like paradise, but its lush coconut palms nurse a hidden problem. Now, the country is preparing to deal with this car-sized problem, before it's too late.

title.children: Tonga has tens of thousands of abandoned cars. Now there's a plan to crush them and ship them home

image.altText: man in suit rubbing hands together next to logo of a white x on black background

props.synopsis: X/Twitter owner Elon Musk says his social media company plans to start charging a small monthly payment to use the platform.  The ASX opens lower and US stocks end little changed ahead of the US Federal Reserve's meeting this week. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Elon Musk says X/Twitter set to charge users, ASX falls, US stocks move sideways as investors await Federal Reserve rates decision

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: And the Australian share market is having a lacklustre day after iron ore prices fell overnight, which has seen the miners weigh on the market. Fortescue Metals (-1.1 per cent) and BHP (-1 per cent) are taking a hit. Wall Street traded sideways as investors await this week's decision by the Federal Reserve, where it is expected to keep official interest rates on hold at 5 to 5.25 per cent. Banks are also weighing with ANZ (-1.2 per cent) and the National Australia Bank (-1.1 per cent) doing the worst. Coal miner New Hope (-3.7 per cent) has gained after a rise in annual profit thanks to record demand coal and higher prices. Gold miners are doing the best with Ramelius Resources (+5 per cent) and Silver Lake Resources (4.3 per cent) making gains on the ASX 200. Doing the worst are semi conductor technology firm Weebit Nano (-7.1 per cent) and Afterpay owner Block (-4.5 per cent). That's after Alyssa Henry, the chief executive of Block's payment provider service, Square, is set to leave the business after more than nine years.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX in the red at midday

children.content: And the Australian share market is having a lacklustre day after iron ore prices fell overnight, which has seen the miners weigh on the market.
Fortescue Metals
(-1.1 per cent) and
BHP
(-1 per cent) are taking a hit.
Wall Street traded sideways as investors await this week's decision by the Federal Reserve, where it is expected to keep official interest rates on hold at 5 to 5.25 per cent.
Banks are also weighing with
ANZ
(-1.2 per cent) and the
National Australia Bank
(-1.1 per cent) doing the worst.
Coal miner
New Hope
(-3.7 per cent) has gained after a rise in annual profit thanks to record demand coal and higher prices.
Gold miners are doing the best with
Ramelius Resources
(+5 per cent) and
Silver Lake Resources
(4.3 per cent) making gains on the ASX 200.
Doing the worst are semi conductor technology firm
Weebit Nano
(-7.1 per cent) and Afterpay owner
Block
(-4.5 per cent).
That's after Alyssa Henry, the chief executive of Block's payment provider service,
Square
, is set to leave the business after more than nine years.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Shares in coal miner New Hope (+3.2 per cent) have climbed to the highest in nearly eight months as strong demand for coal boosted its bottom line. The miner made a net profit of almost $1.1 billion for the 2023 financial year, up nearly 11 per cent from 2022. New Hope chief executive Rob Bishop says strong demand and global supply constraints pushed thermal coal prices to record levels in the first half of the year. “Exceptional performance across the business throughout FY23 enabled our team to capitalise on the market conditions, finishing the year with $730.7 million cash at bank, no debt following the convertible note repurchase and a net asset position of $2,525.3 million,” Mr Bishop said. Global coal consumption is at a record high thanks to strong growth in Asia outpacing falling demand in the US and Europe according to the International Energy Agency. Demand from the two largest coal users, China and India, offset demand falls in developed countries in 2022. New Hope sold coal for an average of $346.73 during the year, up from $281.84 in 2022. Investors get a final dividend of 21 cents a share, but that's down from the 31 cents a share they got in 2022. They also get a special dividend of 9 cents a share, but that is also down from the 25 cents a share they got last year. Mr Bishop says New Hope's results this year are "outstanding' so how come the dividends are lower? with Reuters
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: New Hope profit rises on coal demand

children.content: Shares in coal miner
New Hope
(+3.2 per cent)
have climbed to the highest in nearly eight months as strong demand for coal boosted its bottom line.
The miner made a net profit of almost $1.1 billion for the 2023 financial year, up nearly 11 per cent from 2022.
New Hope chief executive Rob Bishop
says strong demand and global supply constraints pushed thermal coal prices to record levels in the first half of the year.
“Exceptional performance across the business throughout FY23 enabled our team to capitalise on the
market conditions, finishing the year with $730.7 million cash at bank, no debt following the convertible note repurchase and a net asset position of $2,525.3 million,” Mr Bishop said.
Global coal consumption is at a record high thanks to strong growth in Asia outpacing falling demand in the US and Europe according to the International Energy Agency.
Demand from the two largest coal users, China and India, offset demand falls in developed countries in 2022.
New Hope sold coal for an average of $346.73 during the year, up from $281.84 in 2022.
Investors get a final dividend of 21 cents a share, but that's down from the 31 cents a share they got in 2022.
They also get a special dividend of 9 cents a share, but that is also down from the 25 cents a share they got last year.
Mr Bishop says New Hope's results this year are "outstanding' so how come the dividends are lower?
with Reuters

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has been reading the minutes from the Reserve Bank's meeting earlier this month when it kept the official cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent. The Reserve Bank has signalled that inflation remains a clear and present danger to the economy and that another interest rate rise can’t be ruled out. That’s despite evidence that 12 interest rate rises since May last year are continuing to slow the economy with RBA board members warning inflation is still too high. While the RBA board left the cash rate on hold at its meeting a fortnight ago, the minutes released this morning show the battle to get 4.9 percent inflation back into the 2 to 3 percent target zone is far from over. While headline inflation is slowing, the minutes show concern that services inflation might take a while to decline and that the labour market remains tight with the jobless rate hovering around a 50 year low. “Were inflation to remain above target for an even longer period, this could cause inflation expectations to move higher which would likely require an even larger increase,” the minutes warn. Money markets only see an 8 percent probability of a cash rate rise to 4.35 percent at the RBA’s October meeting. Judo Bank economic adviser Warren Hogan sees the outside chance of a November rate rise on Melbourne Cup Day as the final nail in the coffin of inflation. Here's more on the RBA minutes from Peter Ryan.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: RBA says inflation remains a threat

featuredLink.title: RBA can't rule out another rate rise this year, amid rising petrol prices

children.content: Senior business correspondent Peter Ryan has been reading the minutes from the Reserve Bank's meeting earlier this month when it kept the official cash rate on hold at 4.1 per cent.
The Reserve Bank has signalled that
inflation
remains a clear and present danger to the economy and that another interest rate rise can’t be ruled out.
That’s despite evidence that 12 interest rate rises since May last year are continuing to slow the economy with RBA board members warning inflation is still too high.

While the RBA board left the cash rate on hold at its meeting a fortnight ago, the minutes released this morning show the battle to get 4.9 percent inflation back into the 2 to 3 percent target zone is far from over.

While headline inflation is slowing, the minutes show concern that services inflation might take a while to decline and that the labour market remains tight with the jobless rate hovering around a 50 year low.
“Were inflation to remain above target for an even longer period, this could cause inflation expectations to move higher which would likely require an even larger increase,” the minutes warn.
Money markets only see an 8 percent probability of a cash rate rise to 4.35 percent at the RBA’s October meeting.
Judo Bank economic adviser Warren Hogan sees the outside chance of a November rate rise on Melbourne Cup Day as the final nail in the coffin of inflation.
Here's more on the RBA minutes from Peter Ryan.

image.altText: A jet in the air.

props.synopsis: Debris has been found in the search for a F-35 fighter jet in the US which crashed in South Carolina after the pilot ejected and parachuted to safety.

title.children: Debris found from F-35 fighter jet that went missing after pilot ejected

image.altText: A composite image showing Netanyahu and Musk.

props.synopsis: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has urged Elon Musk to strike a balance between protecting free expression and fighting hate speech after weeks of controversy over anti-Semitic content on social media platform X, formerly known as Twitter.

title.children: Israel's Netanyahu urges Elon Musk to balance free speech with fighting anti-Semitism

image.altText: Montara well head platform continues to burn

props.synopsis: In waters around Australia's coastline are about 1 million tonnes of pipelines, moorings, fixed rigs and floating vessels. Many are due for "decommissioning" and operators are contractually obliged to remediate the sites. But the cost is gargantuan, and not everyone wants to pay, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: Our waters are awash with ageing gas and oil infrastructure. What happens when these behemoths are no longer needed?

image.altText: A heavily tattooed man wearing sunglasses is pictured sitting in a car.

props.synopsis: Police in Victoria and New South Wales are searching for a man who is on the run after firing a gun when police attempted to arrest him at a property in northern Victoria.

title.children: Police in two states searching for gunman wanted on kidnap charges

image.altText: A composite image of a Triton unmanned surveillance aircraft and a P-8 Poseidon

props.synopsis: Australia will upgrade its fleet of P-8 patrol aircraft so they can eventually fire missiles out to 1,000 kilometres, while also purchasing another long-range Triton drone from the United States.

title.children: P-8A Poseidon upgrade and fourth Triton drone part of $1.5b boost to RAAF

image.altText: A wombat with mange, image from Katja Gutwein

props.synopsis: It's barely detectable to the human eye, but a microscopic parasite has decimated wombat populations across south-east Australia. Now, researchers have a better idea of how outbreaks occur, as they continue working to find ways to rescue the iconic marsupial from a "horrible, slow death".

title.children: Wombats are solitary creatures. So how is a deadly mite that's wiping out populations being transmitted?

image.altText: A woman on a sporting field looking on

props.synopsis: New Spain coach Montse Tome decides to leave Jenni Hermoso out of her Nations League squad, as a possible boycott still looms.

title.children: Jenni Hermoso left out of Spanish football squad as new coach takes charge for Nations League

image.altText: Prisoners released during a prisoner swap deal between US and Iran, arrive at Doha International Airport.

props.synopsis: Five US citizens have left Iran and landed in Doha in a prisoner swap for five Iranians held in the United States, and the transfer of $US6 billion in frozen Iranian assets.

title.children: US prisoners 'finally coming home' in rare prisoner swap with Iran

image.altText: Justin Trudeau rises to make a statement in the House of Commons.

props.synopsis: Canada expels a top Indian diplomat as it investigates what Prime Minister Justin Trudeau calls credible allegations that India's government may have links to the killing in Canada of a Sikh activist.

title.children: Justin Trudeau says India could be behind killing of Canadian Sikh leader, expels top diplomat

image.altText: Li Shangfu salutes before delivering a speech at the Shangri-La Dialogue in Singapore

props.synopsis: Li Shangfu was only appointed defence minister six months ago but has become the second missing Chinese minister in two months after Qin Gang was stripped of the foreign minister portfolio, with questions of loyalty and corruption believed to behind his apparent ouster.

title.children: 'Disarray for Xi': A second senior Chinese minister disappears into thin air as Beijing cracks down on corruption

image.altText: humpback whale breaching

props.synopsis: Authorities say a 4-metre humpback whale is unlikely to survive after being struck in the head by a boat propeller off the state's north-west coast.

title.children: Humpback whale not expected to survive propeller strike off WA coast

image.altText: A manicured hand holds a mobile phone in a black and white graphic.

props.synopsis: A NSW woman bugged by her spurned ex-lover describes feeling like she was in a film during the ordeal — and experts say her experience is not uncommon as offenders get better at using technology "as a weapon against women".

title.children: Stalking victim felt like she was 'in a Netflix movie', amid spike in tech-assisted tracking

image.altText: A man in a white button up shirt stands with his arms up and holds a black cap in his right hand.

props.synopsis: Ovidio Guzman is one of El Chapo's four sons who inherited his father's trafficking empire after his conviction on US murder and drug charges in 2019.

title.children: Son of drug kingpin 'El Chapo' pleads not guilty to US trafficking charges

image.altText: A graphic showing the silhouette of a man's head in front of a large eye.

props.synopsis: After Queensland passed new legislation, the Northern Territory is now the only jurisdiction in Australia where alleged sexual offenders cannot be publicly named until they are committed to stand trial.

title.children: The NT is the last jurisdiction where accused rapists' identities are suppressed before trial. Activists want that changed

image.altText: Bert Boere holding an air pollution report standing next to Chair of the group Carmen Largaiolli.

props.synopsis: Brooklyn has some of the highest rates of pollution and residents fear the proposed facility could make that worse.

title.children: A Melbourne suburb with some of the highest pollution rates in the state is fighting to stop a facility to treat contaminated soil

image.altText: Kris holding medicine with a dog on an outdoor couch

props.synopsis: After her husband and daughter died in a car crash, Kris McMillan's son bought her a Labrador-cross for company. Max will never go without — but as the cost-of-living crisis worsens, not all pets are so lucky.

title.children: When money is tight, Kris will go without food before letting her dog's bowl go empty
